item.title: How many Switzerlands is a California?
item.description: Overview elide offers tools to manipulate Spatial* objects of all types to compare unfamiliar spatial extents to more familiar benchmarks. This tutorial shows how to use this function to make compelling visual comparisons. Featured skills: elide to move, rotate, and scale Spatial* objects aggregating polygons calculating new polygons from overlapping polygons calculating global and regional centroids plotting spatial data with ggplot2 UPDATE (September 2017): The sf package has been developed to allow better integration of spatial data with the tidyverse.

item.title: Climate effects on structured populations
item.description: [Start playing with the R Shiny app or download the source files from my GitHub to run it locally in RStudio] This interactive model—developed with Chris Johnson—projects the population dynamics a simple organism that has two temperature-sensitive life stages, a juvenile and an adult. We might choose such a model for organisms like frogs (tadpoles/adults), insects (larvae/adults), or other poikilothermic ectotherm. The model assumes that each stage has an optimal temperature for its various life history functions.

item.title: Illuminating the world's demographic dark corners
item.description: [Originally posted on the COM(P)ADRE blog on 28 April 2017] When I first downloaded COMPADRE mere moments after it went public, I was attending the EvoDemoS meeting at Stanford; we were less than 60 km from the nearest matrix population model in the database (Calochortus tiburonensis; Fiedler 1987). My Ph.D. fieldwork brought me considerably closer, and not just because I worked with historic matrix population models collected near the field station.

item.title: Hello World!
item.description: In the spirit of open data, I’ve moved towards posting the raw data and code that underlie my science (see here, here, and here for recent examples). Occaisionally I work on small side projects that make for neat stories, but don’t always make it to a publication. Here is where I’ll post short write ups that highlight ideas and data analysis tools. Hardly regular, hopefully somewhat original…
